Award.AwardTitle: The Sixth International Conference on Mathematical Modeling and Analysis of Populations in Biological Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Sixth International Conference on Mathematical Modeling and Analysis of Populations in Biological Systems will take place at the University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, on October 20-22, 2017. This project support the participation of students (undergraduate and graduate) and early career participants (junior faculty and post-doc fellows) in the conference. This conference will bring together researchers in the mathematical and biological sciences to share their latest findings in the use of mathematical models to study problems arising in population, ecological, and evolutionary dynamics, with a focus on the effects of environmental change. The participants will range from internationally recognized senior researchers to early career researchers and students (postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate). Participants will hear the latest research and findings from their colleagues and have opportunities to present their own research, in both formal and informal settings. During the two and one half days of the conference, there will be five plenary talks by senior researchers and approximate 80 other invited and contributed talks by other participants, including early career participants. It will be a time to establish new collaborations and to refresh established collaborations.

The broad theme of the conference is the analysis of mathematical models for the temporal dynamics of biological populations. A special emphasis will be placed on the effects of environmental/climate change. Specific topics include: population and ecological dynamics; adaptation and evolutionary dynamics; dynamics of infectious diseases and epidemics; dispersal and distribution of populations; invasions and endangered species; management of natural resources. Mathematical models play a central role in population biology where the contribute towards an understanding of the consequences of climate change and of actions that can be taken to mitigate deleterious effects, such as species extinction and loss of biological diversity, habitat disruption and species dispersal, threatened managed systems of renewable natural resources, spread of infectious diseases, evolution of pathogen drug immunity. For this effort to be effective, modelers and biologists need to work in close collaborations. A major contribution of the conference will be to provide a venue for such interdisciplinary collaboration. The PI will invite participants whose research involves model derivation, the mathematical analysis of models, the use of model simulations, and interfacing models with data and observations. The plenary speakers will be encouraged to reach a broader audience, to give surveys of the current state of the research in their field of study, and to suggest new directions of research. The conference website is https://math.la.asu.edu/~icma2017/index.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Sixth International Conference on Mathematical Modeling and Analysis of Populations in Biological Systems (ICMA VI) was held at the University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ, on October 20-22, 2017. The broad, general theme of the conference was the analysis of mathematical models for the temporal dynamics of biological populations. A special emphasis at this sixth conference was placed on the effects of environmental/climate change. Specific topics include, but were not limited to:

  • Population & ecological dynamics
  • Adaptation & evolutionary dynamics
  • Dynamics of infectious diseases and epidemics
  • Dispersal and distribution of populations
  • Invasions and endangered species
  • Management of natural resources

The major goals of ICMA VI were:

  • To enable US scientists to communicate and interact among themselves and with their international colleagues at the highest levels of research;
  • To promote both short and long term collaborations by enhancing existing contacts and creating new ones;
  • To provide opportunities for early career researchers and graduate/undergraduate students to interact formally and informally with internationally renowned scientists;
  • To build an international peer group of mathematicians and biologists interested in mathematical biology in the conference’s focal areas.

The research topics of the conference have a direct impact of the fields of public health, resource management, pest and pathogen control, and disease and epidemic control. Besides departments of mathematics, participants and speakers came from departments, institutes, and research centers in  ecology, evolutionary biology, fish and wildlife, zoology, marine biology, epidemiology, biostatistics, tropical diseases, public health, and atmospheric and climate research.

                More than 75 early career and student (undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral) participants attended the conference and had the opportunity to discuss their research with a significant number of senior researchers in mathematical biology.

                The conference had at total of 133 registered participants (59 of which were female). There were 4 (1 hour) plenary talks, 55 invited (1/2 hour) talks, and 23 (1/2 hour) contributed talks, 7 of whom were local, 53 national, 18 international (Canada, Europe, Africa, China, and India) and 32 of whom were female.  In addition there were 34 student poster presentations (18 female). A talk was also given by the author (Michael Kelly) of the best paper prize awarded by the Journal of Biological Dynamics for the years 2015-2016. The conference was dedicated to the memory of Professor Karl P. Hadeler. A presentation honoring Professor Hadeler’s life and career was given by Professor Horst Thieme. A special issue of the Journal of Biological Dynamics consisting of papers written by speakers will appear in 2019.

                Training of early career and student (undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral) participants was enhanced by their participation at the conference. Early career/postdoctoral students gave 22 talks (10 by females) and 8 poster presentations (3 by females); graduate students gave 8 talks (6 by females) and 27 poster presentations (12 by females); and 10 undergraduate students (6 female) gave poster presentations (some were joint presentations).  

                The conference webpage is:  https://math.la.asu.edu/~icma2017/index.html , which includes a link to the book of abstracts. A special issue of the Journal of Biological Dynamics consisting of papers written by speakers will appear in 2019.
